item.title: Cassidy: Friends gather to remember a member of the original Macintosh team
item.description: Brian Howard worked on the first Apple Macintosh at a time when Silicon Valley was coming into its own. His friends will gather Saturday to remember a life that really was insanely great.
item.dc:creator:
By Mike Cassidy

Mercury News Columnist

item.title: Silicon Valley takes helm in wireless world
item.description: Silicon Valley is looking like a winner in the tug-of-war with wireless carriers over who will control the new world of Internet-connected phones.
item.dc:creator:
By Peter Svensson

Associated Press

item.title: Adobe chief says Apple is hurting itself by shunning Flash
item.description: "Apple's business model is more trying to maintain a proprietary lock," says CEO Shantanu Narayen.
item.dc:creator:
By Ragnhild Kjetland and Rochelle Garner

Bloomberg News

item.title: Feds reviewing Kodak patent complaint against Apple, RIM
item.description: ROCHESTER, N.Y. (AP) — A federal agency that oversees trade disputes said Wednesday it will investigate Eastman Kodak's patent-infringement complaint over digital-camera technology used in iPhones and BlackBerry devices.
item.dc:creator:
By Ben Dobbin

Associated Press

item.title: Apple's Steve Jobs to collaborate on biography of his life
item.description: Apple CEO Steve Jobs has tapped Walter Isaacson, the former editor of Time Magazine and former CEO of CNN, to write an authorized biography of his life, according to the New York Times.
item.dc:creator:
By Troy Wolverton

twolverton@mercurynews.com

item.title: Fighting pandemics like swine flu in digital age
item.description:
Apps, other digital tools
help users keep track,
add data to case reports
item.dc:creator:
By Deborah Yao

Associated Press

item.title: Five Silicon Valley companies fought release of employment data, and won
item.description: Google, Apple and Yahoo are among five Silicon Valley tech giants who say the racial and gender breakdown of their workforce is a trade secret. The companies successfully resisted the Mercury News' efforts to force public disclosure.
item.dc:creator:
By Mike Swift

mswift@mercurynews.com

item.title: Lots of developers already making apps for Apple's iPad
item.description: The iPad may be weeks away from hitting the stores, but it's already creating a surge in the development of new applications '” increasing Apple's lead in programs written for its devices over those running on Google's Android software.
item.dc:creator:
By John Boudreau

jboudreau@mercurynews.com

item.title: Macworld without Apple is diminished but undaunted
item.description: The celebrated trade show goes on despite fewer exhibitors and attendees and the absence of its core attraction.
item.dc:creator:
By Patrick May

pmay@mercurynews.com

item.title: So many apps, so little time
item.description: With an appetite for applications, our iPhone fan goes on a one-day buying binge. Here's what he found.
item.dc:creator:
By Patrick May

pmay@mercurynews.com

item.title: O'Brien: Apple iPad shows company flexing muscles
item.description:
Meet the new Steve Jobs. With Apple's growing clout, he's looking like the old Steve Jobs every day. Ready to take on enemies. Ready to set the rules. And possibly ready to reclaim the mantle as most powerful man in technology.

More about iPad, and other Apple news
item.dc:creator:
By Chris O'Brien

Mercury News Columnist

item.title: Magid: Will Google launch a tablet computer to compete with Apple's iPad?
item.description: There have been no product announcements, but Google's Chrome Web site is displaying "visual explorations of how a Chrome OS tablet UI (user interface) might look in hardware."
item.dc:creator:
By Larry Magid

for Mercury News

item.title: IPad likely to be popular among business travelers and the middle-aged
item.description: Business executives expected to be early adopters of upcoming gadget
item.dc:creator:
By John Boudreau

jboudreau@mercurynews.com

item.title: iPad, anyone? Hospitals looking at the mobile device
item.description: Apple's new creation, the iPad, may be a novelty to many consumers, but hospitals are already starting to abandon paper-and-pen clipboards for hand-held digital tablets
item.dc:creator:
By Bobby Caina Calvan

Sacramento Bee

item.title: Adobe defends Flash, takes a jab at Apple
item.description:
Adobe chief technology officer Kevin Lynch said in a company blog post Tuesday that Flash is ready for smartphones and would work just fine on all of Apple's products, "if and when Apple chooses to allow that for its users."

   Steve Jobs' alleged trash-talking
item.dc:creator:
By Brandon Bailey

bbailey@mercurynews.com
